            Unrefined email chain:
            Email 1:
Dear Mr. Ahmed,                    I'm writing on behalf of Mr. Kane to say that we would like to offer our tender and services to ship your oil from St. Petersburg to Ankara.                    In our experience we have handled similar loadings within the specified time frame. Please see below for our best offer:                    Date of Shipment = 15.06.2021                    Product = M-1000                   Origin = St. Petersburg, Russia                   Destination = Ankara, Turkey                   Quantity = 55.000 MT                   Payment Terms = CIF + HLD                   Payment Mode = 20% IFT / 80% TT                    Our offer is valid until 05.06.2021. If you would like to discuss this further please don't hesitate to call or reply to this email.                    Best regards,                    Felix
Email 2:
Email : ABCDC <Email Address>
Date : 25 June 2021 11:12 AM                   Dear Felix,                   Thank you for your email dated June 15, 2021.                   We have a long-standing relationship with <COMPANY> and greatly appreciate your work with us.                   We can confirm that you are among our preferred shippers.                   Please feel free to submit a quote.                   Kindest regards,
Email 3:
After he receives this email, Felix responds:
Email : Felix <Email Address>
Date : 27 June 2021 11:12 AM                   Dear Mr. Ahmed,                   We are happy to submit a quote for you.                   We have been transporting gasoline to St. Petersburg for over 6 years and have extensive experience with the Russian bureaucracy. Please see below for our best offer:                   Date of Shipment = 15.06.2021                   Product = M-1000                   Origin = St. Petersburg, Russia                   Destination = Ankara, Turkey                   Quantity = 55.000 MT                   Payment Terms = CIF + HLD                   Payment Mode = 20% IFT / 80% TT                   We can also ship your cargo to Dammam or Bandar Abbas, if that is preferable.                   Please confirm the validity of this offer, and we will draw up the contract.

            Email 1:
Hi Susan,                    Could you load 8,000MT of aluminum billets from Port Klang to Karachi, and is your ship chandlers very reliable???                    Sincerely,                    Gert
Email 2:
Hi Gert,
We were informed that the ship that went to Karachi in mid April was, the 5000mt Midas Glory, owned by ICB. After a short delay they loaded 6 x 50MT billets.   
If you want we can assist you to load these cargo on a ship that is due to sail from Port Klang in May. We can also supply you with your bunker, provisions, and ship's stores, if you want. Please check out our website at: http://www.singarama.com.sg or send me an email with the details of the cargo and ship, and we can get back to you.
Regards,
Susan
For your convenience, we have also included a scanned copy of the email for your records. The document was received via e-mail and is an exact copy of the original.
Email 3:
Hi Susan,
I am a ship agent in India. We are having a regular service from Chittagong to India. Can you provide the Ship agency for us in Chittagong. We are having service for Bangladesh.
Thanking You
<Name>
Email 4:
Dear <Name>, I will contact our branch office in Chittagong, Bangladesh and have them contact you. Please give them the details. Susan
Regards,
Susan
Email 5:
Dear Sir
We need Oil cargo for Nigeria for April 15, 2010 for 120000 metric ton, kindly confirm if you can supply and please revert.
Sincerely
<Name>

Hi Liz,                           Can you please check with the buyer to see if they need us to declare CIF or FOB. We can give a trade price on FOB basis. If they need CIF then that needs to be added on the price.                            Thanks,

Dear Mr. Sohal,                    Could you advise a price for us to ship 3,200MT of steel from Nagoya to Singapore. I understand we’ll need to negotiate some carry terms?                    Regards,                    Richard
Email 2:
Dear Sir,

We have asked PT. Tazkia Shipbroking Service as under

”We have ship owner with 2 vessels for charter in onvoy cargo full charter 4500 MT Steel Plate JIS SGCC and 3000 MT steel coil Grade SGCC
Nagoya to India and further shipment India to Italy.”. Please advice when is your vessel next open for such cargo.

Regards

Respected all,
Some time we are not getting good sailings of our vessels due to tonnage/delivery date
issues. What should we do in such circumstances, it is important to send our vessels on voyages
or in case of problems related to cargo, it is better to keep vessels waiting for best tonnages/ best
delivery. Please also let me know your experience in this regard

Regards,
Dinesh

Email 3:

Email 4:

Email 3:

 Dear Sir,

Our ship is berthed at SOHAR for discharging cargo of urea and in few hours the
cargo is going to be discharged and we are approaching for next cargo. If there is
any inquiry regarding any cargo from your side please let me know your proposal.

We are ready to carry any type of cargo as per vessel strength and with 40 days in ballast.

care by owner and it is owner's responsibility to carry any type of inquiry on that
cargoes to the vessel. Please advise in the meaning if there is any inquiry from any
company about any cargo then there is not need to send details through agent.

Kindly note that under above circumstances it will save lots of money which is spent on
agency for discharging cargo in the port.

90W/00N

Regards

            Email 1:
Dear Mr. Cullen,                    I am sorry that we didn’t find a solution for the cargoes on the DFRA vessels.                    I understand that if my offer of $5.25 is not satisfactory, then a freight should be negotiated at the price of an alternative vessel. I look forward to hear your proposal.                    Many thanks,                    Ed
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Ed;                       We regret that DFRA was not able to fulfill the commitment given to you by the master of the sea-going DFRA and express our sympathy at the difficulties this must have caused for your company.               If you would like to enter into discussions for a future contract, we will gladly take this up with you.                If you need some payment for the cargoes already on board, this may be possible.                    We regret this will not be possible at a higher rate than the rate quoted for the passage itself, i.e. $5.25.              We await your instructions.                   With best wishes,                  Ed

The question is: Has the email chain finished? Or will the one who sent the second email, follow up and send a third email?
This is a case where the reader will probably be misled by the formality of the emails. I would advise
Email 3:
I know this will not be possible at a higher rate than the rate quoted for the passage itself, i.e. $5.25. But I thought I would ask anyways. We just found out that we are in serious financial trouble. We will be lucky to make payroll next week. I am hoping that you will be able to find it in your heart to show some mercy. We know you have so much money. You see, you need to trust us. We can do this. We will find a way. Please let us use your ship. We’ll pay back the money once we have time to figure it out. But you need to help us out. Thank you for your time. We know you will be able to make the best decision possible. Ed

By asking about the formal register, you will not be able to have an understanding of the situation. Once you reach the
Email 4:
I’m sorry to hear that you’re in trouble. However, I’m not able to help you. The rules are strict and this is what is written in the contract. I hope you will be able to make payroll somehow. 
-Ed
